Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High Dimensional Multivariate Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Classical multivariate analyses are typically designed for fixed dimensional data, and are often not applicable, even invalid, for high-dimensional data. Analysis of modern high-dimensional data call for novel multivariate statistical approaches in the "large-p, small n" paradigm. This proposal consists of three broad objectives aiming to establish a set of multivariate inferential procedures that are adaptive to high dimensionality, and can accommodate a wide range of model and dependence structures. The investigators will develop new thresholding methods to improve the power performance of the tests for high dimensional means and covariance when the signals are sparse and faint. They also propose bandwidth estimators for the state of the art banding and tapering estimators for covariances, and hence make these two estimation approaches practical. The project will also develop tests for nonparametric functions of high-dimensional covariates in partially linear models.

The multivariate testing procedures obtained from the proposed projects will be readily applicable in selecting gene-sets which are associated with phenotype variations, or responsive to certain treatments in the forms of having different means or covariance. The successful application in gene-set analysis will enhance our understanding of gene regulations at a biological meaningful pathway level. The research will also improve the applications of multivariate analysis in biology, marketing research, and financial risk management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI, together with his collaborators and students, has developed several multivariate test procedures for high-dimensional data, which include thresholding tests for high-dimensional means under sparsity and column-wise dependence (Zhong et al., 2013), ANOVA tests for high-dimensional means under sparsity (Chen et al., 2016), tests for high-dimensional nonparametric functions in reproducing kernel Hilbert space (He et al., 2016), tests for covariance structures with high-dimensional repeated measurements (Zhong et al., 2016). The PI has also developed several inference procedures for low-dimensional parameters in high-dimensional models, which include procedure for testing a single coefficient in high-dimensional linear regression models (Lan et al., 2016), testing coefficients in high-dimensional additive hazard models (Zhong et al., 2015) and a method to test coefficients in high-dimensional models with heteroscedastic variance (Wang et al., 2016).

During the grant support period, the PI co-advised two PhD students including one male and one female students. Both students received their PhD degrees in Statistics in summer 2015. One PhD student at Michigan State University (MSU) worked with the PI on projects related to this grant proposal in 2016. The PI also participated in the 2015 REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) program in Lyman Briggs College at MSU, where the research was introduced to the undergraduate students. In a Lilly teaching project conducted by the PI in spring 2016, the PI integrated the proposed research to teach a graduate statistics course. The data analyses methods for genomic data (a type of high-dimensional data) were introduced in the course.

In summary, the PI has made significant progress in developing statistical inference tools for high-dimensional data sets with the support of the NSF grant. This includes multivariate test procedures and inference procedures for low dimensional parameters in high-dimensional models. In the grant support period, the PI has completed eleven papers, among them eight papers are published or in press, three of them are undergoing reviewing process.  A statistical software package “HMMASE”, aiming at imputing underlying genotypes using RNA sequencing data, was released and is publicly available. Graduate and undergraduate students were involved in various aspects of the research. The PI presented the research findings in various conferences and institutions. The statistical inference procedures obtained from the proposed projects are readily applicable to many fields including genomics, finance and neuroscience.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2016
Modified by: Pingshou Zhong
